awd_titl_txt: Deposition of ash and its effect on heat transfer during the oxy-combustion of biomass and biomass-coal blends.
awd_abstract_narration:
1603249 
Wendt, Jost 

The overall objective of this project is to provide information that will enable implementation of oxy-combustion of biomass and biomass-coal blends for power generation. This technology, when followed by carbon sequestration, has the potential to have significant impact because it can simultaneously produce electricity and decrease CO2 emissions, using essentially conventional equipment. This process requires a knowledge of ash deposition and heat transfer under biomass oxy-combustion conditions, which are the twin thrusts of this research. The international team assembled consists of the Universities of Utah (UU) and North Dakota (UND) in the US and Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST), and  Southeastern University (SEU) in China. 

Scientific objectives are to: 1) validate predictions of ash deposition rates during the oxy-combustion of biomass-coal blends; and 2) understand how these impact boiler chamber radiation. The hypothesis, based on limited preliminary experimental work, is that ash deposition rates are linearly dependent on the concentration of sub-micron particles (PM1) in the flue gas. In extending the work to oxy-biomass combustion, it is sought to understand formation of both the inner binding layer and bulk layer of controlled ash deposits, and to develop and apply experimental information to refine existing models for predicting the ash layer build up and submicron aerosol formation. These models will be employed in conjunction with high fidelity radiative property models in computational fluid dynamic simulations of the combustion scenarios. The simulations will be validated through coordinated experiments in both the US and China, at various scales, for various fuels, covering a range of combustion conditions, including experimental validation at both atmospheric and pressurized oxy-combustion conditions. This international collaborative project is expressly designed to provide the fundamental knowledge that will help bring this technology into practice, for both first generation (atmospheric pressure) and second generation (elevated pressure) oxy-combustion technologies. A US graduate student will assist in some of the experiments in China while Chinese students will participate in US activities.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives pf this research were to understand mechanisms governing the deposition of ash on heat transfer surfaces during the combustion of coal and biomass in practically relevant energy producing systems. Both regular combustion with air and oxy-combustion (suitable for CO2 capture and sequestration) were considered.

The problem was attacked by obtaining data on the size segregated composition of the ash aerosol and that of the ensuing deposit collected on specially controlled heat transfer surfaces. The research differs from other work in that it also focusses on measuring deposition rates, not only deposit compositions. The ash was derived from self-sustained combustion of various coals, biomass fuels, and controlled mixtures of these.  The scale was such that temperatures, species, and particle concentrations were similar to those in practical units, while the system was still sufficiently well-defined to allow systematic experimentation leading to elucidation of mechanisms and subsequent simulation validations. Figure 1 shows a sketch of this experimental rig, together with typical temperature profiles for a coal (denoted as SUFCO1) and also rice husks (denoted as RH).  Figure 1 also shows where deposits and also the pertinent ash aerosol were collected.  The latter was sampled through a special dilution probe and directed to on-line particle size distribution measurement instruments employing particle mobility and light scattering methods to cover the ash aerosol size range from 0.0143µm p <.15.7µm. A low pressure impactor collected particles (0.0324 µm< dp <15.7 µm) for subsequent analysis (by SEM, EDX and in few instances by high resolution STEM/EDX spectral imaging).

Since the combustion rig was operated under laminar flow conditions in the post flame, the data obtained focused on chemical aspects that governed the rate of ash deposition.  In order to extend the results to field conditions with turbulent flow, simulations were necessary, and these were conducted by the University of North Dakota.

In all, 18 fuels were tested, in 32 tests involving both air combustion and oxy-combustion conditions.  The (pulverized) fuels included various coals, rice husks (US and Chinese), torrefied wood, and petroleum coke. Special tests to help isolate critical mechanisms, involved the addition of additives. This large body of data can be mined further to yield additional, hitherto unavailable, information directed towards development of ash partitioning and ash deposition models. 

Ash deposition occurs in two stages.  First, the heat transfer surface must be coated with an “inside” deposit consisting of sub-micron particles.  Without this coating the larger particles would just bounce off because their kinetic energy could not be absorbed. Before this research, it had always been assumed that this inside deposit layer required the vaporization and nucleation of alkali metals, primarily sodium and potassium.  Our research here has shown this not to be true and the composition of the submicron particles not to be important. Rather deposition rates for this layer depended primarily on the presence of sub-micron particles of any composition. Novel STEM analyses examining the outside coating of submicron particles showed also that alkali metals were not essential to enrich the particle surface layer. Rather, the most likely forces causing particle adhesion to the surface were van der Waals forces, which depend only on particle size.  Figure 2 clearly shows that deposition rates for the initial inside layer correlate with the PM1 concentration and not with composition.  The colored insets representing particles whose deposition rates correlate depict vastly different compositions.  This is important, since it suggests that on-line PSD measurements of submicron particles are sufficient to predict deposition rates. Furthermore, the data collected suggest that outer layer deposition rates are completely controlled by particle bounce off since less than 10% of particles impacting the surface ever stick to it.  

Broader aspects are twofold. First: combustion of biomass (with or without coal as an additive) for electricity generation in existing or conventional boilers is a form of bioenergy, and bioenergy with carbon capture and sequestration (BECCS) can remove carbon from the atmosphere, while still generating electricity using conventional systems. It “may be one of the few cost-effective carbon negative opportunities available to mitigate the worst effects of anthropogenic climate change”.  The major impediment to using this technology is the problem of ash deposition on boiler tubes, which is the issue addressed in this project. Second: this project has been a model for international collaboration.  It has brought together international scholars from Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST), China, and from Chalmers University, Sweden. Researchers from both China and Sweden worked together with us in our laboratory, with 3 joint peer reviewed papers from the US/China and US/Swedish group respectively.  The research also played a critical role in the education of US graduate and undergraduate students.  Results have been reported to the research community in 11 accepted peer reviewed papers.
